title: Identify the given values
text:
Let's start by identifying the given values. We have:
Initial pressure, $$P=2.00$$ atm
Initial volume, $$V_i=100$$ L
Final volume,
$$V_f=50.0$$ L
Number of moles, $$n=6.00$$ mol
Heat capacity at constant pressure,
$$c_P=29.3$$ $$ rac{J}{Kmol}$$

title: Use the Ideal Gas Law
text:
The Ideal Gas Law relates pressure, volume, and temperature:
PV $$=$$ nRT

First, let's calculate the initial temperature
$$T_i$$ by rearranging the equation:
$$T_i$$ $$=$$ $$ rac{PV}{nR}$$
Where R is the ideal gas constant: $$R=0.0821$$ L atm/(K mol)

title: Understanding isobaric processes
text: Since the process is isobaric (constant pressure), the change in temperature can be determined when the volume changes, while pressure remains constant.

title: Use the work done formula
text: In an isobaric process, the work done (W) by the gas is given by:\n$$W=P\left(V_f-V_i\right)$$

title: Calculating the internal energy change
text:
The first law of thermodynamics states:
ΔU $$=$$ Q - W
For an isobaric process, the heat added (Q) is given by:
$$Q=\operatorname{nc_P}\left(T_f-T_iight)$$
Substitute to find ΔU:
ΔU $$=$$ $$\operatorname{nc_P}\left(T_f-T_iight)-P\left(T_f-T_iight)$$
Utilize the values for $$n$$, $$c_P$$, and the temperature change calculated from ideal gas behavior to find ΔU.
